reference_answer:
The Student newspaper at the University of Edinburgh is a significant publication in the landscape of student media. Founded in 1887 by the renowned writer Robert Louis Stevenson, it holds the distinction of being the oldest student newspaper in the United Kingdom. Over its long history, The Student has played an essential role in providing news and commentary relevant to students at the university.

Key figures associated with The Student include notable politicians such as Gordon Brown, Robin Cook, and Lord Steel of Aikwood, who have contributed writings during their time as students. These associations highlight the newspaper's influence and its ability to attract prominent voices within academia and beyond.

The evolution of The Student has seen it transition from being closely linked with the university to becoming an independent entity in 1992. This independence allowed for editorial freedom but also introduced financial challenges. In 2002, increasing debts forced the newspaper to temporarily cease operations. However, following its relaunch, The Student managed to regain stability and recognition within student journalism circles, winning several awards that underscored its quality and impact.

Despite these successes, The Student has faced ongoing challenges typical of print media in a digital age, including financial sustainability and adapting to changing consumption habits among students. Nonetheless, it continues to serve as an important platform for student voices at the University of Edinburgh, maintaining its legacy while navigating contemporary issues within journalism.

query: What year did the Scottish Varsity rugby match between Edinburgh University and the University of St Andrews resume, and where was it first played after its resurrection?
reference_contexts:
['=== Sport ===

Student sport at Edinburgh consists of clubs covering the more traditional rugby, football, rowing and judo, to the more unconventional korfball, gliding and mountaineering. In 2021, the university had over 65 sports clubs run by Edinburgh University Sports Union (EUSU).
The Scottish Varsity, known as the "world's oldest varsity match", is a rugby match played annually against the University of St Andrews dating back over 150 years. Discontinued in the 1950s, the match was resurrected in 2011 and was staged in London at the home of London Scottish RFC. It is played at the beginning of the academic year, and since 2015 has been staged at Murrayfield Stadium in Edinburgh.
The Scottish Boat Race is an annual rowing race between the Glasgow University Boat Club and the Edinburgh University Boat Club, rowed between competing eights on the River Clyde in Glasgow, Scotland. Started in 1877, it is believed to be the third-oldest university boat race in the world, predated by the Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race and the Harvard–Yale Regatta.
Edinburgh athletes have repeatedly been successful at the Olympic Games: Sprinter Eric Liddell won gold and bronze at the 1924 Summer Olympics. At the 1948 Summer Olympics, alumnus Jackie Robinson won a gold medal with the American Basketball team. Trap shooter Bob Braithwaite secured a gold medal at the 1968 Summer Olympics. Cyclist Sir Chris Hoy won six gold and one silver medal between 2000 and 2012. Rower Dame Katherine Grainger won a gold medal at the 2012 Summer Olympics, and four further silver medals between 2000 and 2016. Edinburgh was the most successful UK university at the 2012 Games with two gold medals from Hoy and one from Grainger.


=== Student activism ===
There are a number of campaigning societies at the university. The largest of these include the environment and poverty campaigning group People & Planet and Amnesty International Society. International development organisations include Edinburgh Global Partnerships, which was established as a student-led charity in 1990. There is also a significant left-wing presence on campus, including an anti-austerity group, Edinburgh University Anarchist Society, Edinburgh University Socialist Society, Edinburgh Young Greens, Feminist Society, LGBT+ Pride, Marxist Society, and Students for Justice in Palestine.
Protests, demonstrations and occupations are regular occurrences at the university. The activist group People & Planet took over Charles Stewart House in 2015 and again in 2016 in protest over the university's investment in companies active in arms manufacturing or fossil fuel extraction. In May 2015, a security guard was charged in relation to the occupations.


==== Gaza protest ====

In May 2024, student activists set up a protest camp in the Old College Quad, with some also beginning a hunger strike, and demanded divestment from companies they alleged supported the Israeli invasion of the Gaza Strip. The campaign, backed by more than 600 staff and the students' union, specifically targeted the university's investments in Alphabet Inc. and Amazon, and its relationship with investment firm BlackRock. In response, Principal Mathieson emphasized that the university would respect peaceful protest rights, while also defending its investment practices. The university subsequently established a working group to review its investment policies related to "armaments and controversial weapons" and launched a consultation on ethical investing principles. The protest camp was dismantled in June.


=== Student co-operatives ===
There are three student-run co-operatives associated with the University: Edinburgh Student Housing Co-operative (ESHC), providing affordable housing for 106 students; the Hearty Squirrel Food Cooperative, providing local, organic and affordable food to students and staff; and the SHRUB Coop, a swap and re-use hub aimed at reducing waste and promoting sustainability. Of these, only the Hearty Squirrel Co-operative operates on campus. ESHC is based on the Bruntsfield Links south of the University's central campus, and hosts students from all three city universities and Edinburgh College. The SHRUB co-operative was formed partly by University of Edinburgh students but is now run by interested members from across Edinburgh. The co-operatives form part of the Students for Cooperation network.']
reference_answer:
The Scottish Varsity rugby match between Edinburgh University and the University of St Andrews resumed in 2011. After its resurrection, the match was first played at the home of London Scottish RFC in London.

Reference:
- The match was discontinued in the 1950s.
- It was resurrected in 2011.
- Initially staged in London at the home of London Scottish RFC.

query: Name two student-run co-operatives associated with the University of Edinburgh that focus on sustainability and describe their primary functions.
reference_contexts:
['=== Sport ===

Student sport at Edinburgh consists of clubs covering the more traditional rugby, football, rowing and judo, to the more unconventional korfball, gliding and mountaineering. In 2021, the university had over 65 sports clubs run by Edinburgh University Sports Union (EUSU).
The Scottish Varsity, known as the "world's oldest varsity match", is a rugby match played annually against the University of St Andrews dating back over 150 years. Discontinued in the 1950s, the match was resurrected in 2011 and was staged in London at the home of London Scottish RFC. It is played at the beginning of the academic year, and since 2015 has been staged at Murrayfield Stadium in Edinburgh.
The Scottish Boat Race is an annual rowing race between the Glasgow University Boat Club and the Edinburgh University Boat Club, rowed between competing eights on the River Clyde in Glasgow, Scotland. Started in 1877, it is believed to be the third-oldest university boat race in the world, predated by the Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race and the Harvard–Yale Regatta.
Edinburgh athletes have repeatedly been successful at the Olympic Games: Sprinter Eric Liddell won gold and bronze at the 1924 Summer Olympics. At the 1948 Summer Olympics, alumnus Jackie Robinson won a gold medal with the American Basketball team. Trap shooter Bob Braithwaite secured a gold medal at the 1968 Summer Olympics. Cyclist Sir Chris Hoy won six gold and one silver medal between 2000 and 2012. Rower Dame Katherine Grainger won a gold medal at the 2012 Summer Olympics, and four further silver medals between 2000 and 2016. Edinburgh was the most successful UK university at the 2012 Games with two gold medals from Hoy and one from Grainger.


=== Student activism ===
There are a number of campaigning societies at the university. The largest of these include the environment and poverty campaigning group People & Planet and Amnesty International Society. International development organisations include Edinburgh Global Partnerships, which was established as a student-led charity in 1990. There is also a significant left-wing presence on campus, including an anti-austerity group, Edinburgh University Anarchist Society, Edinburgh University Socialist Society, Edinburgh Young Greens, Feminist Society, LGBT+ Pride, Marxist Society, and Students for Justice in Palestine.
Protests, demonstrations and occupations are regular occurrences at the university. The activist group People & Planet took over Charles Stewart House in 2015 and again in 2016 in protest over the university's investment in companies active in arms manufacturing or fossil fuel extraction. In May 2015, a security guard was charged in relation to the occupations.


==== Gaza protest ====

In May 2024, student activists set up a protest camp in the Old College Quad, with some also beginning a hunger strike, and demanded divestment from companies they alleged supported the Israeli invasion of the Gaza Strip. The campaign, backed by more than 600 staff and the students' union, specifically targeted the university's investments in Alphabet Inc. and Amazon, and its relationship with investment firm BlackRock. In response, Principal Mathieson emphasized that the university would respect peaceful protest rights, while also defending its investment practices. The university subsequently established a working group to review its investment policies related to "armaments and controversial weapons" and launched a consultation on ethical investing principles. The protest camp was dismantled in June.


=== Student co-operatives ===
There are three student-run co-operatives associated with the University: Edinburgh Student Housing Co-operative (ESHC), providing affordable housing for 106 students; the Hearty Squirrel Food Cooperative, providing local, organic and affordable food to students and staff; and the SHRUB Coop, a swap and re-use hub aimed at reducing waste and promoting sustainability. Of these, only the Hearty Squirrel Co-operative operates on campus. ESHC is based on the Bruntsfield Links south of the University's central campus, and hosts students from all three city universities and Edinburgh College. The SHRUB co-operative was formed partly by University of Edinburgh students but is now run by interested members from across Edinburgh. The co-operatives form part of the Students for Cooperation network.']
reference_answer:
Two student-run cooperatives associated with the University of Edinburgh that focus on sustainability are:

1. **Hearty Squirrel Food Cooperative**: This cooperative provides local, organic, and affordable food to students and staff. It operates on campus and emphasizes sustainable practices by sourcing food locally and organically.

2. **SHRUB Coop (Swap and Re-use Hub)**: The SHRUB Coop is aimed at reducing waste and promoting sustainability through its focus on swapping and reusing items. Although initially formed partly by University of Edinburgh students, it now includes members from across Edinburgh. Its primary function is to encourage sustainable consumption habits among the community.

These cooperatives are part of the Students for Cooperation network, which supports initiatives that promote cooperative principles and sustainability.

reference_answer:
The 2024 Gaza protest at the University of Edinburgh was significant for several reasons, both in terms of the demands made by student activists and the subsequent response from the university.

### Demands:
1. **Divestment**: The primary demand of the protesters was divestment from companies they alleged were supporting the Israeli invasion of the Gaza Strip. Specifically, they targeted the university's investments in Alphabet Inc., Amazon, and its relationship with investment firm BlackRock.
   
2. **Ethical Investment Review**: Beyond specific companies, there was a broader call for the university to review and potentially alter its investment policies concerning ethical considerations.

### University Response:
1. **Respect for Protest Rights**: Principal Mathieson emphasized that while the university would respect the rights of students to engage in peaceful protest, it also defended its current investment practices.
   
2. **Establishment of a Working Group**: In response to the protests, the university established a working group tasked with reviewing its investment policies related to "armaments and controversial weapons." This indicates an openness to re-evaluating how investments align with ethical standards.

3. **Consultation on Ethical Investing Principles**: The university launched a consultation process regarding ethical investing principles, suggesting a willingness to engage in dialogue about the broader implications of its financial decisions.

### Significance:
- **Student Activism and Influence**: The protest highlighted the active role that student groups play in influencing university policies, particularly concerning social justice and ethical considerations.
  
- **Institutional Accountability**: By responding with both immediate actions (such as dismantling the protest camp) and longer-term measures (like forming a working group), the university demonstrated an acknowledgment of the need for accountability regarding its investment choices.

- **Broader Ethical Discourse**: The event contributed to ongoing discussions about ethical investing in educational institutions, potentially setting a precedent for how universities might handle similar demands in the future.

Overall, the 2024 Gaza protest at the University of Edinburgh underscored the power of student activism and prompted institutional reflection on investment ethics.

reference_answer: Joseph Lister is a notable alumnus of the university who made significant contributions to the field of antiseptic surgery. He is credited with founding antiseptic surgical methods by introducing the use of carbolic acid (phenol) as an antiseptic, which drastically reduced post-surgical infections and mortality rates. His work laid the foundation for modern sterile surgical techniques, transforming medical practice and improving patient outcomes in surgeries.

reference_answer:
One notable philosopher from the list is David Hume. Hume was a central figure in the Scottish Enlightenment and made significant contributions to philosophy, particularly in epistemology, ethics, and metaphysics. His work "A Treatise of Human Nature" laid the groundwork for modern philosophical empiricism by arguing that all human knowledge arises from sensory experiences. He also explored ideas about causation, personal identity, and skepticism, influencing later philosophers such as Immanuel Kant.

One notable economist is Adam Smith. Often referred to as the father of modern economics, Smith's seminal work "The Wealth of Nations" laid the foundations for classical economics. In it, he introduced key concepts like the division of labor, the function of markets, and the idea of an "invisible hand" guiding economic prosperity through individual self-interest. His ideas have profoundly shaped economic theory and policy.

Both Hume and Smith were instrumental in shaping their respective fields, with Hume's philosophical inquiries challenging existing notions of knowledge and morality, while Smith's economic theories provided a framework for understanding market dynamics and the benefits of free trade.

query: Which Nobel Prize laureate associated with the University of Edinburgh was recognized for their work on the mechanism of ATP synthesis, and what is the significance of this discovery?
reference_contexts:
['=== Nobel and Nobel equivalent prizes ===

As of October 2024, 20 Nobel Prize laureates, with 20 awards, have been affiliated with the university as alumni, faculty members or researchers (three additional laureates acted as administrative staff), including one of the fathers of quantum mechanics Max Born, theoretical physicist Peter Higgs, Cognitive scientist Geoffrey E. Hinton (also a Turing Award winner), chemist Sir Fraser Stoddart, immunologist Peter C. Doherty, economist Sir James Mirrlees, discoverer of Characteristic X-ray (Charles Glover Barkla) and the mechanism of ATP synthesis (Peter D. Mitchell), and pioneer in cryo-electron microscopy (Richard Henderson) and in-vitro fertilisation (Sir Robert Edwards).  Turing Award winners Robin Milner Leslie Valiant, and mathematician Sir Michael Atiyah, Fields Medalist and Abel Prize laureate, are associated with the university.
In the following table, the number following a person's name is the year they received the Nobel prize. In particular, a number with an asterisk (*) means the person received the award while they were working at the university (including emeritus staff). A name underlined implies that this person has been listed previously (i.e., multiple affiliations).


=== Heads of state and government ===


== In popular culture ==
The University of Edinburgh has featured prominently in a number of works of popular culture.

The events of the Burke and Hare murders, involving Edinburgh lecturer Robert Knox and the anatomical department, have made a wide range of appearances in popular culture. They became the basis for Robert Louis Stevenson's short story The Body Snatcher (1884), and most recently in 2010 for Burke & Hare, a black comedy film starring Simon Pegg and Andy Serkis. Scenes were filmed at the old School of Anatomy.
Many of Arthur Conan Doyle's works drew inspiration from his mentors at the university. Joseph Bell, a lecturer and surgeon famous for drawing conclusions from minute observations, became the archetype for Conan Doyle's fictional detective Sherlock Holmes. William Rutherford, Conan Doyle's physiology professor provided the template for Professor Challenger, the protagonist of his science fiction work The Lost World (1912). Edinburgh is also Challenger's alma mater in the books.
Dr. Fu Manchu, a fictional supervillain created by Sax Rohmer in 1912, stated that "I am a doctor of philosophy from Edinburgh, a doctor of law from Christ's College, a doctor of medicine from Harvard. My friends, out of courtesy, call me 'Doctor'." In 2010, Fu Manchu's connections with the University where he supposedly obtained a doctorate were investigated in a mockumentary by Miles Jupp (also an Edinburgh alumnus) for BBC Radio 4.
In the movie Journey to the Center of the Earth (1959), an adaptation of Jules Verne's novel of the same name, the protagonist Sir Oliver Lindenbrook is a Professor of Geology at the university. An early scene where Lindenbrook addresses the students is filmed at the central quadrangle of Old College.
The historical film Chariots of Fire (1981) is based on the story of Olympic runner and Edinburgh graduate Eric Liddell, and includes scenes filmed outside of Assembly Hall, New College. Liddell is played by Ian Charleson, who is also an Edinburgh alumnus.
In the novel The Last King of Scotland (1998) by Giles Foden, the fictional protagonist Dr. Nicholas Garrigan is a medical doctor recently graduated from Edinburgh. The 2006 film of the same name stars James McAvoy in the role of Dr. Garrigan with the same background.
In the American television show NCIS (2003–present), the chief medical examiner, Dr. Donald "Ducky" Mallard studied medicine at Edinburgh. Ari Haswari, the show's main antagonist for the first two seasons, also studied medicine at Edinburgh.
In the novel One Day (2009), the lead characters Dexter and Emma both graduated from Edinburgh. A feature film based on the book, also titled One Day and starring Anne Hathaway and Jim Sturgess was released in August 2011, with some scenes filmed at the university. A Netflix adaptation of the movie started production in 2021, with filming occurring in the grounds of Old College in 2022.
The BBC legal drama Garrow's Law (2009–2011) was largely filmed in Edinburgh, despite being set in London. Old College and the Playfair Library are prominently featured.
The thriller television series Clique (2017–2019) produced by BBC Three focuses on two students at the university. The series was shot largely on location in Edinburgh, including The Meadows, Old College, and Potterrow.
Fast & Furious 9 (2021), partly set in Edinburgh, featured scenes in and around Old College filmed in September 2019.


== See also ==


== Notes ==


== References ==


== Further reading ==']
reference_answer:
The Nobel Prize laureate associated with the University of Edinburgh who was recognized for their work on the mechanism of ATP synthesis is Peter D. Mitchell. He received the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1978.

**Significance of the Discovery:**

1. **Chemiosmotic Theory:** Peter D. Mitchell proposed the chemiosmotic theory, which explains how ATP (adenosine triphosphate) is produced in cells. This process occurs during cellular respiration and photosynthesis.

2. **ATP Synthesis Mechanism:** According to the chemiosmotic theory, a proton gradient across a membrane (such as the inner mitochondrial membrane or thylakoid membrane in chloroplasts) drives ATP synthesis. The energy from this gradient is used by the enzyme ATP synthase to convert ADP (adenosine diphosphate) and inorganic phosphate into ATP.

3. **Fundamental Biological Process:** ATP is often referred to as the "energy currency" of the cell because it provides the necessary energy for various cellular processes, including muscle contraction, nerve impulse propagation, and chemical synthesis.

4. **Impact on Biochemistry:** Mitchell's work fundamentally changed our understanding of bioenergetics and has had a profound impact on fields such as biology, medicine, and biotechnology. It provided insights into how cells harness energy from nutrients and sunlight.

5. **Recognition and Legacy:** The chemiosmotic theory was initially controversial but eventually gained widespread acceptance after experimental evidence supported it. Mitchell's contribution to science is considered one of the most important discoveries in biochemistry during the 20th century.

Peter D. Mitchell's work on ATP synthesis not only earned him a Nobel Prize but also laid the groundwork for further research into cellular energy processes and their applications in medicine and technology.

Many of Arthur Conan Doyle's works drew inspiration from his mentors at the university. Joseph Bell, a lecturer and surgeon famous for drawing conclusions from minute observations, became the archetype for Conan Doyle's fictional detective Sherlock Holmes. William Rutherford, Conan Doyle's physiology professor provided the template for Professor Challenger, the protagonist of his science fiction work The Lost World (1912). Edinburgh is also Challenger's alma mater in the books.
Dr. Fu Manchu, a fictional supervillain created by Sax Rohmer in 1912, stated that "I am a doctor of philosophy from Edinburgh, a doctor of law from Christ's College, a doctor of medicine from Harvard. My friends, out of courtesy, call me 'Doctor'." In 2010, Fu Manchu's connections with the University where he supposedly obtained a doctorate were investigated in a mockumentary by Miles Jupp (also an Edinburgh alumnus) for BBC Radio 4.
In the movie Journey to the Center of the Earth (1959), an adaptation of Jules Verne's novel of the same name, the protagonist Sir Oliver Lindenbrook is a Professor of Geology at the university. An early scene where Lindenbrook addresses the students is filmed at the central quadrangle of Old College.
The historical film Chariots of Fire (1981) is based on the story of Olympic runner and Edinburgh graduate Eric Liddell, and includes scenes filmed outside of Assembly Hall, New College. Liddell is played by Ian Charleson, who is also an Edinburgh alumnus.
In the novel The Last King of Scotland (1998) by Giles Foden, the fictional protagonist Dr. Nicholas Garrigan is a medical doctor recently graduated from Edinburgh. The 2006 film of the same name stars James McAvoy in the role of Dr. Garrigan with the same background.
In the American television show NCIS (2003–present), the chief medical examiner, Dr. Donald "Ducky" Mallard studied medicine at Edinburgh. Ari Haswari, the show's main antagonist for the first two seasons, also studied medicine at Edinburgh.
In the novel One Day (2009), the lead characters Dexter and Emma both graduated from Edinburgh. A feature film based on the book, also titled One Day and starring Anne Hathaway and Jim Sturgess was released in August 2011, with some scenes filmed at the university. A Netflix adaptation of the movie started production in 2021, with filming occurring in the grounds of Old College in 2022.
The BBC legal drama Garrow's Law (2009–2011) was largely filmed in Edinburgh, despite being set in London. Old College and the Playfair Library are prominently featured.
The thriller television series Clique (2017–2019) produced by BBC Three focuses on two students at the university. The series was shot largely on location in Edinburgh, including The Meadows, Old College, and Potterrow.
Fast & Furious 9 (2021), partly set in Edinburgh, featured scenes in and around Old College filmed in September 2019.

Joseph Bell was a lecturer and surgeon at the University of Edinburgh known for his exceptional observational skills. His ability to draw conclusions from minute details greatly influenced Arthur Conan Doyle during his time as a student there. This influence is evident in Doyle's creation of Sherlock Holmes, who embodies similar traits of acute observation and deductive reasoning.

Professor Challenger, another character created by Arthur Conan Doyle, was inspired by William Rutherford, Doyle’s physiology professor at the University of Edinburgh. Professor Challenger appears as the protagonist in Doyle's science fiction work "The Lost World" (1912). In this novel, Challenger is depicted as a bold and eccentric scientist, much like Rutherford, who leads an expedition to explore prehistoric life on a remote plateau.

Thus, Joseph Bell inspired Sherlock Holmes through his observational prowess, while William Rutherford influenced the creation of Professor Challenger with his dynamic personality and scientific expertise.

The University of Edinburgh has made notable appearances across various works of popular culture, spanning multiple genres. Here are some specific examples:

1. **Historical and Crime Fiction**: The Burke and Hare murders, involving an Edinburgh lecturer, inspired Robert Louis Stevenson's short story "The Body Snatcher" (1884) and the 2010 black comedy film *Burke & Hare*, starring Simon Pegg and Andy Serkis.

2. **Literary Inspiration**: Arthur Conan Doyle’s works were influenced by his time at the university. His mentor, Joseph Bell, inspired the character Sherlock Holmes, while William Rutherford was the template for Professor Challenger in "The Lost World" (1912).

3. **Supervillain Lore**: In Sax Rohmer's creation of Dr. Fu Manchu, a fictional supervillain claims to have earned a doctorate from Edinburgh. This connection was humorously explored in a 2010 BBC Radio 4 mockumentary by Miles Jupp.

4. **Adventure and Science Fiction**: The 1959 film *Journey to the Center of the Earth*, based on Jules Verne's novel, features Sir Oliver Lindenbrook as a Professor of Geology at Edinburgh, with scenes filmed in Old College’s central quadrangle.

5. **Sports Drama**: The historical film *Chariots of Fire* (1981) tells the story of Olympic runner Eric Liddell, an Edinburgh graduate, including scenes shot outside Assembly Hall and New College.

6. **Political Thriller**: In Giles Foden's novel *The Last King of Scotland* (1998), the protagonist Dr. Nicholas Garrigan is a recent medical school graduate from Edinburgh. The 2006 film adaptation features James McAvoy in this role.

7. **Crime Drama**: The American TV show *NCIS* (2003–present) includes characters like Dr. Donald "Ducky" Mallard and antagonist Ari Haswari, both of whom studied medicine at Edinburgh.

8. **Romantic Drama**: In the novel *One Day* (2009), protagonists Dexter and Emma are Edinburgh graduates. The 2011 film adaptation features scenes filmed at the university, with a Netflix series adaptation starting production in 2021, including filming at Old College.

9. **Legal Drama**: The BBC legal drama *Garrow's Law* (2009–2011) was largely filmed in Edinburgh, despite its London setting, prominently featuring Old College and the Playfair Library.

10. **Thriller Series**: The BBC Three series *Clique* (2017–2019), focusing on two students at the university, was shot on location in Edinburgh, including areas like The Meadows, Old College, and Potterrow.

11. **Action/Adventure**: In *Fast & Furious 9* (2021), partly set in Edinburgh, scenes were filmed around Old College in September 2019.

These examples illustrate how the University of Edinburgh has been represented across a diverse range of genres, from historical dramas to thrillers and action films.

query: How did Emma Wedgwood's early experiences and family background influence her involvement with education, particularly at Maer Hall?
reference_contexts:
['== See also ==

Emma Darwin (née Wedgwood; 2 May 1808 – 2 October 1896) was an English woman who was the wife and first cousin of Charles Darwin. They were married on 29 January 1839 and were the parents of ten children, seven of whom survived to adulthood.


== Early life ==
Emma Wedgwood was born at the family estate of Maer Hall in Maer, Staffordshire, the youngest of seven children of Josiah Wedgwood II and his wife Elizabeth "Bessie" (née Allen). Her grandfather Josiah Wedgwood had made his fortune in pottery, and like many others who were not part of the aristocracy, they were nonconformist, belonging to the Unitarian church. Charles Darwin was her first cousin; their shared grandparents were Josiah and Sarah Wedgwood, and as the Wedgwood and Darwin families were closely allied, they had been acquainted since childhood.
She was close to her sister Fanny, the two being known by the family as the "Doveleys", and was charming and messy, accounting for her nickname, "Little Miss Slip-Slop".: 9  She helped her older sister Elizabeth with the Sunday school which was held in Maer Hall laundry, writing simple moral tales to aid instruction and giving 60 village children their only formal training in reading, writing and religion.: 17 
The Wedgwoods visited Paris for six months in 1818. Though Emma was only 10 at the time, the strangeness and interest of arriving in France remained in her memory.
In January 1822 the 13-year-old Emma and her sister Fanny were taken by their mother for a year at Mrs Mayer's school at Greville House, on Paddington Green, London, at what was then the semi-rural village of Paddington. Emma was by then "one of the show performers on the piano", to the extent that on one occasion she was invited along to play for George IV's Mrs Fitzherbert. After this time, Emma was taught by her elder sisters as well as tutors in some subjects. For the rest of her life Emma continued to be a fine pianist, with a tendency to speed up slow movements. She had piano lessons from Moscheles, and allegedly "two or three" from Chopin.
In 1825 Josiah took his daughters on a grand tour of Europe, via Paris to near Geneva to visit their Aunt Jessie (Madame de Sismondi, née Allen, wife of the historian Jean Charles Leonard de Sismondi) and then on.  In the following year the Sismondis visited Maer, then took Emma and her sister Fanny back to near Geneva to stay with them for eight months. When her father went to collect them he was accompanied by their cousin, Caroline Darwin, and also took Charles Darwin, Caroline's brother, as far as Paris, where they all met up again before returning home in July 1827. She was keen on outdoor sports and loved archery.: 21 
At Maer on 31 August 1831 she was with her family when they helped Charles Darwin to overturn his father's objections to letting Charles go on an extended voyage on the Beagle. During the voyage Charles' sisters kept him informed of news including the death of Emma's sister Fanny at the age of 26, political developments and family gossip.
Emma herself had turned down several offers of marriage, and after her mother suffered a seizure and became bedridden Emma and her older sister Elizabeth spent a lot of time nursing their mother, though with the help of many servants. Emma and Elizabeth took turns spending time away from their mother, and Emma spent several months each year away from home, staying with friends or family.: 57–58']
reference_answer:
Emma Wedgwood's early life was significantly shaped by her family background and experiences, which influenced her involvement in educational activities, especially at Maer Hall. Here are some key factors:

1. **Family Influence**: Emma was born into the prominent Wedgwood family, known for their success in pottery and nonconformist religious beliefs as Unitarians. This environment likely fostered a sense of responsibility and community service.

2. **Close Family Ties**: Her close relationship with her sister Fanny, whom she helped at the Sunday school held in Maer Hall laundry, indicates a strong familial bond that encouraged collaborative efforts in education. The sisters were known as the "Doveleys," highlighting their partnership in these activities.

3. **Educational Environment**: Emma's involvement in writing simple moral tales for instruction and assisting with teaching reading, writing, and religion to 60 village children reflects her active role in providing educational opportunities. This was particularly significant given that it offered the only formal training many of these children received.

4. **Nonconformist Values**: The Wedgwood family's nonconformist beliefs likely emphasized education as a means of personal and moral development, aligning with their Unitarian values which often supported progressive ideas about education and social responsibility.

5. **Personal Skills and Interests**: Emma's talents in music and her inclination towards outdoor sports suggest she had diverse interests that could have contributed to a well-rounded approach to education, encouraging creativity and physical activity alongside traditional learning.

Overall, Emma Wedgwood's early experiences and family background fostered an environment where education was valued as a tool for personal growth and community service, influencing her active involvement in educational activities at Maer Hall.

Emma Wedgwood was born at the family estate of Maer Hall in Maer, Staffordshire, the youngest of seven children of Josiah Wedgwood II and his wife Elizabeth "Bessie" (née Allen). Charles Darwin was her first cousin; their shared grandparents were Josiah and Sarah Wedgwood, and as the Wedgwood and Darwin families were closely allied, they had been acquainted since childhood.
She was close to her sister Fanny, the two being known by the family as the "Doveleys", and was charming and messy, accounting for her nickname, "Little Miss Slip-Slop".: 9  She helped her older sister Elizabeth with the Sunday school which was held in Maer Hall laundry, writing simple moral tales to aid instruction and giving 60 village children their only formal training in reading, writing and religion.: 17

Emma was by then "one of the show performers on the piano", to the extent that on one occasion she was invited along to play for George IV's Mrs Fitzherbert. After this time, Emma was taught by her elder sisters as well as tutors in some subjects. For the rest of her life Emma continued to be a fine pianist, with a tendency to speed up slow movements. She had piano lessons from Moscheles, and allegedly "two or three" from Chopin.
In 1825 Josiah took his daughters on a grand tour of Europe, via Paris to near Geneva to visit their Aunt Jessie (Madame de Sismondi, née Allen, wife of the historian Jean Charles Leonard de Sismondi) and then on. She was keen on outdoor sports and loved archery.: 21 
At Maer on 31 August 1831 she was with her family when they helped Charles Darwin to overturn his father's objections to letting Charles go on an extended voyage on the Beagle. During the voyage Charles' sisters kept him informed of news including the death of Emma's sister Fanny at the age of 26, political developments and family gossip.
Emma herself had turned down several offers of marriage, and after her mother suffered a seizure and became bedridden Emma and her older sister Elizabeth spent a lot of time nursing their mother, though with the help of many servants. Emma and Elizabeth took turns spending time away from their mother, and Emma spent several months each year away from home, staying with friends or family.: 57–58']
reference_answer:
Emma Wedgwood and Charles Darwin shared a close familial bond from childhood due to being first cousins. Their families, the Wedgwoods and Darwins, were closely allied through marriage ties between Josiah Wedgwood and Sarah Wedgwood, making Emma and Charles both grandchildren of this union. This connection meant that they had been acquainted since early childhood, fostering a relationship built on familiarity and shared family experiences.

During their youth, Emma was known for her charm and musical talent, often referred to as "Little Miss Slip-Slop" due to her messy nature. Her close bond with her sister Fanny, the two being called the "Doveleys," highlights her nurturing personality, which likely contributed positively to her relationship with Charles.

Their relationship evolved significantly over time, particularly when Emma played a crucial role in supporting Charles's decision to embark on the HMS Beagle voyage. On 31 August 1831, at Maer Hall, she was instrumental in helping Charles overcome his father's objections to this extended journey. This pivotal moment not only demonstrated her influence and support but also marked the beginning of their partnership as they grew closer.

Their relationship eventually transitioned into a romantic one, leading to their marriage on 29 January 1839. Emma became an integral part of Charles Darwin’s life, supporting him through his scientific endeavors and raising ten children together, seven of whom survived to adulthood. Her influence extended beyond personal support; she was also known for her moral guidance and intellectual companionship, which played a significant role in shaping the environment in which Darwin developed his groundbreaking theories.

Overall, Emma Wedgwood's relationship with Charles Darwin evolved from childhood familiarity to deep familial support and eventually into a partnership that significantly impacted both their lives.

reference_answer:
Emma Wedgwood played a supportive role in helping Charles Darwin overcome his father's objections to embarking on the extended voyage of the HMS Beagle. On August 31, 1831, Emma was present with her family when they assisted Charles in persuading his father to allow him to go on this significant scientific expedition.

During this period, Emma faced several personal challenges. She had turned down multiple marriage proposals and spent considerable time caring for her mother, who suffered a seizure and became bedridden. This responsibility required Emma and her older sister Elizabeth to take turns nursing their mother, which was demanding given the need for constant care despite having many servants. Additionally, Emma often spent months away from home each year, staying with friends or family, likely as a respite from these caregiving duties.

These personal challenges highlight Emma's resilience and dedication both to her family and in supporting Charles Darwin during a pivotal moment in his life.

query: On what date did Emma Wedgwood accept Charles Darwin's marriage proposal, and where were they married?
reference_contexts:
['== Marriage ==

Emma Wedgwood accepted Charles' marriage proposal on 11 November 1838 at the age of 30, and they were married on 29 January 1839 at St. Peter's Anglican Church in Maer.  Their cousin, the Reverend John Allen Wedgwood, officiated the marriage.
After a brief period of residence in London, they moved permanently to Down House, located in the rural village of Down, around 16 miles (26 km) from St Paul's Cathedral and about two hours by coach and train to London Bridge. The village was later renamed Downe.
Charles and Emma raised their 10 children in a distinctly non-authoritarian manner, and several of them later achieved considerable success in their chosen careers: George, Francis and Horace became Fellows of the Royal Society.
Emma Darwin is especially remembered for her patience and fortitude in dealing with her husband's long-term illness. She also nursed her children through frequent illnesses, and endured the deaths of three of them: Anne, Mary, and Charles Waring. By the mid-1850s she was known throughout the parish for helping in the way a parson's wife might be expected to, giving out bread tokens to the hungry and "small pensions for the old, dainties for the ailing, and medical comforts and simple medicine" based on Dr. Robert Darwin's old prescription book.
In a letter dated 5 July 1844, Charles Darwin entrusted to Emma the responsibility of publishing his work, in the case of his sudden death. Charles lived and published On the Origin of Species in 1859.
Emma often played the piano for Charles, and in Charles' 1871 The Descent of Man, and Selection in Relation to Sex, Darwin spent several pages on the evolution of musical ability by means of sexual selection.']
reference_answer: Emma Wedgwood accepted Charles Darwin's marriage proposal on 11 November 1838. They were married on 29 January 1839 at St. Peter's Anglican Church in Maer. The Reverend John Allen Wedgwood, their cousin, officiated the wedding.

Charles and Emma Darwin raised their ten children in a distinctly non-authoritarian manner. This approach to parenting allowed for an environment where individuality and personal growth were encouraged, rather than strict adherence to rigid rules or expectations.

Several of their children achieved considerable success in their respective careers. Notably, three of their sons—George, Francis, and Horace—became Fellows of the Royal Society, a prestigious recognition that highlights significant contributions to scientific knowledge.

Emma Darwin is also remembered for her resilience and dedication as a mother. She demonstrated patience and fortitude while caring for Charles during his long-term illness and supported her children through frequent illnesses. Tragically, she endured the loss of three of their children: Anne, Mary, and Charles Waring. Beyond her family responsibilities, Emma was known in her community for her charitable work, providing assistance to those in need by distributing bread tokens, small pensions, dainties, medical comforts, and simple medicines based on Dr. Robert Darwin's old prescription book.

Overall, the Darwins' approach to parenting fostered an environment of support and encouragement that contributed to their children's achievements and Emma's notable community involvement.

query: How did Emma's religious beliefs influence her initial concerns about marrying Charles Darwin, and what specific passage from the Gospel of John did she ask him to read?
reference_contexts:
['== Religious views ==
Emma's religious beliefs were founded on Unitarianism, which emphasises inner feeling over the authority of religious texts or doctrine. Her views were not simple and unwavering, and were the result of intensive study and questioning.
Darwin was open about his scepticism before they became engaged, and she discussed with him the tension between her fears that differences of belief would separate them, and her desire to be close and openly share ideas. Following their marriage, they shared discussions about Christianity for several years. She valued his openness, and his genuine uncertainty regarding the existence and nature of God, which gradually developed into agnosticism. This may have been a bond between them, without necessarily resolving the tensions between their views.

By early 1837 Charles Darwin was already speculating on transmutation of species. Having decided to marry, he visited Emma on 29 July 1838 and told her of his ideas on transmutation. On 11 November 1838, he returned and proposed to Emma. Again he discussed his ideas, and about ten days later she wrote to him: "When I am with you I think all melancholy thoughts keep out of my head but since you are gone some sad ones have forced themselves in, of fear that our opinions on the most important subject should differ widely. My reason tells me that honest & conscientious doubts cannot be a sin, but I feel it would be a painful void between us. I thank you from my heart for your openness with me & I should dread the feeling that you were concealing your opinions from the fear of giving me pain. It is perhaps foolish of me to say this much but my own dear Charley we now do belong to each other & I cannot help being open with you. Will you do me a favour? yes I am sure you will, it is to read our Saviour's farewell discourse to his disciples which begins at the end of the 13th Chap of John. It is so full of love to them & devotion & every beautiful feeling. It is the part of the New Testament I love best. This is a whim of mine it would give me great pleasure, though I can hardly tell why I don't wish you to give me your opinion about it."
Darwin had already wondered about the materialism implied by his ideas. The letter shows Emma's tension between her fears that differences of belief would separate them, and her desire to be close and openly share ideas. Emma cherished a belief in the afterlife, and was concerned that they should "belong to each other" for eternity. The passage in the Gospel of John referred to in Emma's letter says "Love one another" (13:34), then describes Jesus  saying "I am the way, the truth and the life: no man cometh unto the Father, but by me" (14:6). Desmond and Moore note that the section continues: "Whoever does not abide in me is thrown away like a branch and withers; such branches are gathered, thrown into the fire and burned" (15:6). As disbelief later gradually crept over Darwin, he could "hardly see how anyone ought to wish Christianity to be true; for if so the plain language of the text seems to show that the men who do not believe, and this would include my Father, Brother and almost all my best friends, will be everlastingly punished. And this is a damnable doctrine."
Following their marriage in January 1839, they shared discussions about Christianity for many years. They socialised with the Unitarian clergymen James Martineau and John James Tayler, and read their works as well as those of other Unitarian and liberal Anglican authors such as Francis William Newman whose Phases of faith described a spiritual journey from Calvinism to theism, all part of widespread and heated debate on the authority of Anglicanism. In Downe Emma attended the Anglican village church, but as a Unitarian had the family turn round in silence when the Trinitarian Nicene Creed was recited.
Soon after their marriage, Emma wrote to Charles "while you are acting conscientiously & sincerely wishing, & trying to learn the truth, you cannot be wrong", and although concerned at the threat to faith of the "habit in scientific pursuits of believing nothing till it is proved", her hope that he did not "consider his opinion as formed" proved correct. Methodical conscientious doubt as a state of inquiry rather than disbelief made him open to nature and revelation, and they remained open with each other.']
reference_answer:
Emma's religious beliefs significantly influenced her initial concerns about marrying Charles Darwin. As a Unitarian, she placed great emphasis on inner feeling over strict adherence to religious texts or doctrines. This foundation led her to value open and honest discussions about deeply held beliefs, including those concerning religion.

Before their marriage, Emma was aware of Darwin's skepticism regarding Christianity. She expressed concern that differences in their views on such an important subject could create a "painful void" between them. Despite understanding that having conscientious doubts should not be considered sinful, she feared these differences might separate them emotionally and spiritually. Her desire for openness and honesty with Charles was paramount; she wanted to ensure they could share ideas freely without concealing their true beliefs from each other.

To address her concerns and foster a deeper connection, Emma asked Darwin to read a specific passage from the Gospel of John: "our Saviour's farewell discourse to his disciples which begins at the end of the 13th Chap of John." This passage includes Jesus' teachings on love and devotion, particularly emphasizing "Love one another" (John 13:34). Emma cherished this part of the New Testament for its expressions of love and beautiful feelings. She hoped that engaging with this scripture would help bridge any gaps in their beliefs and reinforce their bond.

In summary, Emma's religious views led her to prioritize open communication about faith when considering marriage to Charles Darwin. Her request for him to read a specific passage from John reflects her desire to connect on a spiritual level despite differing beliefs.

reference_answer:
After marrying Emma in January 1839, Charles Darwin's religious views underwent a gradual evolution influenced by ongoing discussions with her and their shared intellectual environment. Initially, Darwin was open about his skepticism regarding traditional Christian beliefs, which he discussed candidly with Emma before they were engaged. This openness continued after their marriage, as they engaged in extensive conversations about Christianity over several years.

Emma held Unitarian beliefs that emphasized inner feeling over strict adherence to religious texts or doctrines. Despite her concerns about potential differences in belief between them, she valued Darwin's honesty and his genuine uncertainty regarding the existence and nature of God. This mutual openness allowed for a respectful exchange of ideas without necessarily resolving their differing views.

Their discussions were enriched by interactions with Unitarian clergymen like James Martineau and John James Tayler, as well as reading works from other liberal thinkers such as Francis William Newman. These influences contributed to the broader debate on religious authority and personal belief systems that surrounded them.

Emma's letters reveal her hope that Darwin would continue to seek truth conscientiously and sincerely, without considering his opinions fully formed. This approach of methodical doubt—viewing inquiry rather than disbelief as a state of mind—allowed Darwin to remain open to both nature and revelation.

Over time, Darwin's skepticism deepened into agnosticism. He expressed difficulty reconciling the implications of Christian doctrine with his scientific understanding, particularly the idea that disbelief would lead to eternal punishment for himself and those close to him. This tension between faith and reason was a significant factor in his evolving views on religion after marriage.

In summary, Darwin's religious views evolved from skepticism to agnosticism through ongoing discussions with Emma, exposure to Unitarian and liberal theological ideas, and the internal conflict between scientific inquiry and traditional Christian beliefs.

Unitarianism played a significant role in shaping the religious discussions between Emma and Charles Darwin. Emma's religious views were rooted in Unitarianism, which emphasizes personal inner feeling over strict adherence to religious texts or doctrines. This perspective allowed for open dialogue and exploration of differing beliefs without rigid dogma, fostering an environment where both Emma and Charles could discuss their ideas openly.

Their social interactions with Unitarian clergymen like James Martineau and John James Tayler further reflected this openness and willingness to engage in intellectual and spiritual exploration. These clergymen were part of a broader movement that questioned traditional Anglican authority, aligning with the Unitarian emphasis on individual conscience and reason.

By socializing with Martineau and Tayler, Emma and Charles engaged with contemporary religious thought that was more liberal and questioning, which resonated with their own discussions about Christianity. This engagement provided them with diverse perspectives and reinforced their commitment to exploring beliefs through dialogue rather than dogma.

Emma's Unitarian background also influenced her approach to the differences in belief between herself and Charles. She valued open communication and honesty, as evidenced by her letter encouraging Charles to read a passage from the Gospel of John that she cherished. This reflects the Unitarian emphasis on love and personal connection over doctrinal conformity.

Overall, Unitarianism facilitated an environment where Emma and Charles could maintain their relationship despite differing beliefs, emphasizing mutual respect, open inquiry, and the importance of shared values like love and understanding.

query: What was the significance of "The Grove" after Emma Darwin's time, and what decision did Fitzwilliam College make regarding its gatehouse, Grove Lodge?
reference_contexts:
['== Later life and the Darwin grounds ==

Shortly before she turned 74, her husband Charles died at 73 on 19 April 1882. Subsequently, Emma spent the summers in Down House. She bought a large house called The Grove on Huntingdon Road in Cambridge, and lived there during the winters. Emma Darwin died in 1896. Her son Francis had a house, which he named Wychfield, built in the grounds of The Grove. He lived there during most winters, spending summers in Gloucestershire. Emma's son Horace also had a house built in the grounds, and named it The Orchard.
The Grove is now the central building of Fitzwilliam College, and provides common room facilities for graduates, Fellows and senior members. In January 2009, Cambridge City Council gave the College planning permission to demolish its gatehouse, Grove Lodge, which now forms part of Murray Edwards College. After local residents and academics expressed concern and there was a campaign against the demolition, the college council decided to reconsider possible alternative uses; their decision at the end of September 2009 was to keep and refurbish Grove Lodge. Architects, consultants and builders were appointed for conversion work, which when completed in September 2011 provided five new studies for Fellows.


== Children ==

The Darwins (after Charles' death in 1882, Emma and Francis) also brought up Francis' son Bernard Darwin (1876-1961) after the death of Bernard's mother a few days after he was born.


== Cultural references ==
In 2001 a biography of Emma was published written by Edna Healey, though it has been criticised for attempting to give credit to Emma for her husband's ideas, whereas other historians agree she had little, if any, scientific input.
In 2008 Mrs Charles Darwin's Recipe Book was published, with profits going to the Darwin Correspondence Project at Cambridge University.
The 2009 film Creation focuses in part on the relationship between Charles and Emma. Emma was played by Jennifer Connelly.
A boarding house at Shrewsbury School is named in her honour.


== Darwins buried at Downe ==
Eight members of the Darwin family are buried at St Mary's Church, Downe. Darwins buried at Downe include: Bernard Darwin and his wife Elinor Monsell, who taught her husband's cousin Gwen (Darwin) Raverat, engraver and author of Period Piece; Charles Waring Darwin; Elizabeth Darwin, "Aunt Bessy"; Emma Darwin, Charles Darwin's wife; Erasmus Alvey Darwin; Mary Eleanor Darwin; Henrietta Etty Darwin, later Litchfield, "Aunt Etty". Emma Darwin's sister Elizabeth Wedgwood and Aunt Sarah Wedgwood are also buried together at St Mary's.


== See also ==

Emma Darwin (novelist)
List of coupled cousins
Darwin–Wedgwood family
Emma Darwin: A Century of Family Letters


== Notes ==


== References ==
Browne, E. Janet (1995), Charles Darwin: vol. 1 Voyaging, London: Jonathan Cape, ISBN 1-84413-314-1
Browne, E. Janet (2002), Charles Darwin: vol. 2 The Power of Place, London: Jonathan Cape, ISBN 0-7126-6837-3
Darwin, Charles (1837–1838), Notebook B: [Transmutation of species], Darwin Online, CUL-DAR121, retrieved 20 December 2008
Darwin, Charles (1838), Notebook C: [Transmutation of species], Darwin Online
Darwin, Charles (1887), Darwin, Francis (ed.), The life and letters of Charles Darwin, including an autobiographical chapter, London: John Murray, retrieved 4 November 2008
Darwin, Charles (1958), Barlow, Nora (ed.), The Autobiography of Charles Darwin 1809–1882. With the original omissions restored. Edited and with appendix and notes by his granddaughter Nora Barlow, London: Collins, retrieved 4 November 2008
Desmond, Adrian; Moore, James (1991), Darwin, London: Michael Joseph, Penguin Group, ISBN 0-7181-3430-3
Freeman, R. B. (1984), . Darwin Pedigrees, London: printed for the author, retrieved 15 September 2009
Freeman, R. B. (2007), Charles Darwin: A companion (2d online ed.), The Complete Works of Charles Darwin Online, retrieved 18 June 2008
Litchfield, Henrietta Emma (1904), Emma Darwin, wife of Charles Darwin. A century of family letters, London: John Murray, retrieved 18 February 2013']
reference_answer:
**Significance of "The Grove" After Emma Darwin's Time**

After Emma Darwin's time, "The Grove," which she had purchased on Huntingdon Road in Cambridge, became an integral part of Fitzwilliam College. It serves as the central building of the college and provides common room facilities for graduates, Fellows, and senior members.

**Decision Regarding Grove Lodge**

Initially, in January 2009, Cambridge City Council granted Fitzwilliam College planning permission to demolish its gatehouse, known as Grove Lodge, which had become part of Murray Edwards College. However, this decision faced opposition from local residents and academics who expressed concern over the demolition. As a result, the college council reconsidered their plans.

In September 2009, after evaluating alternative uses for Grove Lodge, the college decided to keep and refurbish it instead of demolishing it. The conversion work was completed in September 2011, resulting in five new studies being created for Fellows. This decision preserved a part of the historical structure while adapting it for contemporary use within the college.

Overall, "The Grove" transitioned from a personal residence to an important educational facility, and the preservation of Grove Lodge reflects a commitment to maintaining its historical significance.

The relationship between Charles Darwin and his wife Emma is portrayed with depth and nuance in various cultural references. A notable depiction of their relationship can be found in the 2009 film "Creation." In this film, Emma Darwin is played by Jennifer Connelly. The movie focuses on part of their life together, particularly highlighting the dynamics of their marriage during a period when Charles was developing his groundbreaking theories.

The film explores both the personal and intellectual aspects of their relationship, illustrating how they supported each other despite differing views on some matters, such as religion. Emma is shown as a supportive partner who played a significant role in Charles's life, providing emotional support and managing household affairs that allowed him to focus on his scientific work.

Additionally, a biography of Emma written by Edna Healey was published in 2001, which has been critiqued for attempting to attribute some credit for Charles Darwin’s ideas to Emma. This suggests an ongoing interest in understanding the extent of her influence and support in his life and work.

Overall, cultural references like "Creation" and biographical works contribute to a richer understanding of the personal dynamics between Charles and Emma Darwin, portraying their relationship as one of mutual respect and profound partnership amidst the backdrop of scientific discovery.

The Geological Society of London, known commonly as the Geological Society, is a learned society based in the United Kingdom. It is the oldest national geological society in the world and the largest in Europe, with more than 12,000 Fellows.
Fellows are entitled to the postnominal FGS (Fellow of the Geological Society), over 2,000 of whom are Chartered Geologists (CGeol). The Society is a registered charity, no. 210161. It is also a member of the Science Council, and is licensed to award Chartered Scientist to qualifying members.
The mission of the society is: "Making geologists acquainted with each other, stimulating their zeal, inducing them to adopt one nomenclature, facilitating the communication of new facts and ascertaining what is known in their science and what remains to be discovered".


== History ==
The Society was founded on 13 November 1807 at the Freemasons' Tavern, Great Queen Street, in the Covent Garden district of London. It was partly the outcome of a previous club known as the Askesian Society. There were 13 founder members: William Babington, James Parkinson, Humphry Davy, George Bellas Greenough, Arthur Aikin, William Allen, Jacques Louis, Comte de Bournon, Richard Knight, James Laird, James Franck, William Haseldine Pepys, Richard Phillips, and William Phillips. It received its royal charter on 23 April 1825 from George IV.
Since 1874, the Society has been based at Burlington House, Piccadilly, London. This building houses the Society's library, which contains more than 300,000 volumes of books and journals. It is a member of the UK Science Council.
In 1907 a decision was made by the Society to admit women as Associates, under the condition they distinguished themselves as geological investigators or submitted their own original research. Women were first allowed to become Fellows of the Society in 1919. Margaret Crosfield became the first, due to alphabetical primacy, of the first eight women to be elected Fellows of the Society, on 21 May 1919. 
In 1991, the Society merged with the Institution of Geologists, which had been formed in 1977 to represent the geological profession.
The Society is a member of the European Federation of Geologists.
The Society celebrated its bicentenary in 2007. It ran programmes in the geosciences in Britain and abroad, under the auspices of the science writer and palaeontologist Professor Richard Fortey, the president that year.


== Specialist and regional groups ==
The Society has 24 specialist groups and 15 regional groups which serve as an opportunity for those with specific interests to meet and discuss their subject or region. They are all free for members to join and some are open to non-members.
The Regional Groups are:

The Specialist Groups are:


== Publications ==
The society publishes two of its own journals, the (formerly Quarterly) Journal of the Geological Society and the Quarterly Journal of Engineering Geology & Hydrogeology. It also publishes the magazine Geoscientist for Fellows, and has a share in Geology Today, published by Blackwell Science.
It also co-publishes journals and publishes on behalf of other organisations. These include Petroleum Geoscience with the European Association of Geoscientists and Engineers; Geochemistry: Exploration, Environment, Analysis with the Association of Applied Geochemists; Journal of Micropalaeontology for The Micropalaeontological Society; Proceedings of the Yorkshire Geological Society for the Yorkshire Geological Society; and Scottish Journal of Geology for the Geological Societies of Edinburgh and Glasgow.


== Past presidents ==

The society counts many famous geologists amongst its past presidents. These include pioneers of geology William Buckland, Adam Sedgwick, Roderick Impey Murchison, Charles Lyell, Henry Thomas De la Beche, Thomas Henry Huxley, Joseph Prestwich, Archibald Geikie, Jethro Teall, and Charles Lapworth. Later well-known names include Alfred Harker, Arthur Elijah Trueman, Herbert Harold Read, Frederick Shotton, and Janet Watson.']
reference_answer:
The Geological Society was founded on 13 November 1807 at the Freemasons' Tavern, located in Great Queen Street, Covent Garden district of London. The founder members included:

1. William Babington
2. James Parkinson
3. Humphry Davy
4. George Bellas Greenough
5. Arthur Aikin
6. William Allen
7. Jacques Louis Comte de Bournon
8. Richard Knight
9. James Laird
10. James Franck
11. William Haseldine Pepys
12. Richard Phillips
13. William Phillips

These individuals were instrumental in establishing the Society, which is recognized as the oldest national geological society in the world and the largest in Europe.

The Geological Society publishes two of its own journals:

1. The (formerly Quarterly) Journal of the Geological Society
2. The Quarterly Journal of Engineering Geology & Hydrogeology

In addition to these, the society also co-publishes or publishes on behalf of other organizations for various scientific publications. These include:

- **Petroleum Geoscience** with the European Association of Geoscientists and Engineers.
- **Geochemistry: Exploration, Environment, Analysis** with the Association of Applied Geochemists.
- **Journal of Micropalaeontology** for The Micropalaeontological Society.
- **Proceedings of the Yorkshire Geological Society** for the Yorkshire Geological Society.
- **Scottish Journal of Geology** for the Geological Societies of Edinburgh and Glasgow.

query: Who was awarded the Wollaston Medal by the Geological Society in 2006, and what hypothesis did they originate?
reference_contexts:
["== Past presidents ==

The society counts many famous geologists amongst its past presidents. These include pioneers of geology William Buckland, Adam Sedgwick, Roderick Impey Murchison, Charles Lyell, Henry Thomas De la Beche, Thomas Henry Huxley, Joseph Prestwich, Archibald Geikie, Jethro Teall, and Charles Lapworth. Later well-known names include Alfred Harker, Arthur Elijah Trueman, Herbert Harold Read, Frederick Shotton, and Janet Watson.


== Scientific awards and funds ==
In 1831, it began issuing an annual scientific award for geology, known as the Wollaston Medal. This is still the Society's premier medal, which in 2006 was awarded to James Lovelock, the originator of the Gaia hypothesis.


=== Medals awarded by the Society ===

Major Edward D'Ewes Fitzgerald Coke Medal
Murchison Medal
President's Awards

R. H. Worth Award
Sue Tyler Friedman Medal
William Smith Medal
Wollaston Medal


=== Funds administered by the Society ===
Lyell Fund
Murchison Fund
Wollaston Fund
William Smith Fund

John Stevens Henslow (6 February 1796 – 16 May 1861) was an English Anglican priest, botanist and geologist. He is best remembered as friend and mentor to Charles Darwin.


== Early life ==
Henslow was born at Rochester, Kent, the son of a solicitor John Prentis Henslow, who was the son of John Henslow.
Henslow was educated at St. John's College, Cambridge where he graduated as 16th wrangler in 1818, the year in which Adam Sedgwick became Woodwardian Professor of Geology."]
reference_answer:
The Wollaston Medal for 2006 was awarded to James Lovelock. He is known as the originator of the Gaia hypothesis.

**Explanation:**

- The context information specifies that the Wollaston Medal is a prestigious award given annually by the Geological Society.
- In 2006, this medal was awarded to James Lovelock.
- Additionally, it mentions that James Lovelock originated the Gaia hypothesis, which is a scientific theory proposing that the Earth and its biological systems behave as a huge single entity or superorganism.

Thus, combining these pieces of information from the context provided:

**Answer:** In 2006, the Wollaston Medal was awarded to James Lovelock, who originated the Gaia hypothesis.

reference_answer:
The Geological Society administers several funds named after notable figures in geology. Two of these are:

1. **Lyell Fund** - Named after Charles Lyell, a pioneering geologist known for his work on the principles of geology and uniformitarianism.

2. **Murchison Fund** - Named after Roderick Impey Murchison, another prominent figure in geology recognized for his contributions to stratigraphy and paleontology.

These funds are part of the Society's efforts to support geological research and honor the legacy of these influential figures.

query: What significant role did Adam Sedgwick play in Henslow's early career, and how did this influence Henslow's studies in geology?
reference_contexts:
['== Early life ==
Henslow was born at Rochester, Kent, the son of a solicitor John Prentis Henslow, who was the son of John Henslow.
Henslow was educated at St. John's College, Cambridge where he graduated as 16th wrangler in 1818, the year in which Adam Sedgwick became Woodwardian Professor of Geology.


== Early career ==
Henslow graduated in 1818. He already had a passion for natural history from his childhood, which largely influenced his career, and he accompanied Sedgwick in 1819 on a tour in the Isle of Wight where he learned his first lessons in geology. He also studied chemistry under Professor James Cumming and mineralogy under Edward Daniel Clarke. In the autumn of 1819 he made valuable observations on the geology of the Isle of Man (Trans. Geol. Soc., 1821) and in 1820 and 1821 he investigated the geology of parts of Anglesey, the results being printed in the first volume of the Transactions of the Cambridge Philosophical Society (1822). The Philosophical Society was founded in November 1819 by a group at Cambridge with Professors Farish, Lee, and Sedgwick and Henslow (at that time not yet a professor). The idea and initial impetus for the society originated from Sedgwick and Henslow.
Meanwhile, Henslow had studied mineralogy with considerable zeal, so that on the death of Clarke he was in 1822 appointed professor of mineralogy in the University of Cambridge. Two years later he took holy orders. Botany, however, had claimed much of his attention, and to this science he became more and more attached, so that he gladly resigned the chair of mineralogy in 1827, two years after becoming professor of botany. As a teacher both in the classroom and in the field he was eminently successful. He was a correspondent of John James Audubon who in 1829 named Henslow's sparrow (Centronyx henslowii) after him.
From 1821 Henslow had begun organising a herbarium of British flora, supplementing his own collecting with a network which expanded over time to include his friends and family, and the botanists William Jackson Hooker and John Hutton Balfour, as well as about 30 of his students. As a mineralogist he had used Haüy's laws of crystallography to analyse complex crystals as transformations of "the primitive form of the species" of crystal, and when he moved to botany in 1825 he sought similarly precise laws to group plant varieties into species, often including as varieties plants that respected taxonomists had ranked as separate species. He followed the understanding of the time that species were fixed as created but could vary within limits, and hoped to analyse these limits of variation. By a method he called "collation", Henslow prepared sheets with several plant specimens, each labelled with the collector, date and place of collection, comparing the specimens to show the variation within the species. His A Catalogue of British Plants was first published in October 1829, and became a set book for his lecture course.
Henslow is remembered as friend and mentor to his pupil Charles Darwin, and for inspiring him with a passion for natural history. The two met in 1828. Earlier that year, Darwin joined the course and along with other students helped to collect plants of Cambridgeshire. Henslow became his tutor, and it was not long before he marked out Darwin as a promising student. In 1830 Henslow experimented on varying the conditions of garden grown wild plants to produce various forms of the plant. In 1835 Henslow published Principles of Descriptive and Physiological Botany as a textbook based on this lecture course.
In the summer of 1831 Henslow was offered a place as naturalist to sail aboard the survey ship HMS Beagle on a two-year voyage to survey South America, but his wife dissuaded him from accepting. Seeing a perfect opportunity for his protégé, Henslow wrote to the ship's captain Robert Fitzroy telling him that Darwin was the ideal man to join the expedition team. During the voyage, Darwin corresponded with Henslow, and collected plants with him in mind. In particular, when first arriving at the Galápagos Islands Darwin noted "I certainly recognize S America in Ornithology, would a botanist?", and went on to collect plant specimens carefully labelled by island and date. He also labelled the mockingbirds he caught, and initially thought these were varieties but while arranging these bird specimens on the last lap of the voyage he began wondering if they could be species, a possibility which would "undermine the stability of Species". Henslow's teaching continued to influence Darwin's work on evolution.
Besides Darwin, other famous students of Henslow included Miles Joseph Berkeley, Cardale Babington, Leonard Jenyns, Richard Thomas Lowe and William Hallowes Miller.']
reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick played a pivotal role in Joseph Dalton Henslow's early career by influencing his initial foray into the field of geology. In 1819, shortly after graduating from St. John’s College, Cambridge, Henslow accompanied Sedgwick on a tour to the Isle of Wight. This experience was crucial as it provided Henslow with his first lessons in geology under Sedgwick's guidance. The mentorship and exposure during this tour significantly shaped Henslow's interest and expertise in geological studies.

Sedgwick’s influence extended beyond just imparting knowledge; he also played a foundational role in the establishment of the Cambridge Philosophical Society, which was founded in November 1819 by Sedgwick along with other professors including Henslow. This society provided an intellectual platform for Henslow to further his studies and share his geological observations, such as those made on the Isle of Man and parts of Anglesey.

Overall, Adam Sedgwick's mentorship and collaboration were instrumental in nurturing Henslow’s passion for geology during the formative years of his career. This early influence laid a strong foundation for Henslow's subsequent contributions to natural history and his role as an educator and mentor to future scientists like Charles Darwin.
