reference_answer:
In April 1836, Captain FitzRoy proposed to Charles Darwin that they collaborate on publishing an account of their voyage. Specifically, FitzRoy suggested that he would have control over arranging and incorporating Darwin's journal entries into the publication alongside his own narrative. He asked Darwin if he was willing to join him in this endeavor, indicating that he found the "chit-chat details" of Darwin's journal potentially valuable for inclusion.

Darwin responded positively to FitzRoy's proposal. He expressed his willingness to participate in publishing their accounts together, provided that FitzRoy deemed the materials from Darwin's journal worth including. This response shows Darwin's readiness to collaborate and contribute to a joint publication with FitzRoy, respecting the captain's discretion over how the material would be used.

query: Who were some of the individuals that reviewed Charles Darwin's journal after his return, and what was their general opinion about its publication?
reference_contexts: ['=== Journal and remarks ===\nSoon after Darwin\'s return, he was at a party hosted by Fanny and Hensleigh Wedgwood for their relatives on 4 December 1836. They agreed to review his journal. The physician and travel writer Henry Holland looked at some pages and "thought that it would not be worth while to publish it alone, as it would be partly going over the same ground with the Captain", leaving Darwin "more perplexed" but "becoming rather inclined to the plan of mixing up long passages with Capt Fitzroy." He would "go on with the geology and let the journal take care of itself", but Emma Wedgwood did not think Holland "any judge as to what is amusing or interesting", and like Catherine thought it should be published by itself, not "mixed up with Capt. FitzRoy\'s". Fanny and Hensleigh found the "Journal so interesting, that it is quite difficult to stop to criticize". Though "not in general a good reader of travels", he "found no part of yours tedious." They had "read a great deal of it aloud too" as a more severe test, and concluded it had "more variety and a greater number of interesting portions" than other travel books, "the less it is mixed up with the Captains the better." \nAfter advice from Broderip, FitzRoy wrote on 30 December that "One volume might be for King—another for you—and a third for me. The profits if any, to be divided into three equal portions—What think you of such a plan?" Darwin agreed, and began work on his volume. In March he told Fox "I am now hard at work and give up every thing else for it. Our plan is as follows.— Capt. FitzRoy writes two volumes, out of the materials collected during both the last voyage under Capt. King to T. del Fuego and during our circumnavigation.— I am to have the third volume, in which I intend giving a kind of journal of a naturalist, not following however always the order of time, but rather the order of position.— The habits of animals will occupy a large portion, sketches of the geology, the appearance of the country, and personal details will make the hodge-podge complete.— Afterwards I shall write an account of the geology in detail, and draw up some Zoological papers.— So that I have plenty of work, for the next year or two, and till that is finished I will have no holidays."']
reference_answer:
After Charles Darwin returned from his voyage, several individuals reviewed his journal. These included:

1. **Henry Holland**: A physician and travel writer who examined some pages of Darwin's journal. He suggested that it might not be worthwhile to publish the journal alone as it would overlap with Captain FitzRoy's accounts. This left Darwin more perplexed about how to proceed.

2. **Fanny Wedgwood** and **Hensleigh Wedgwood**: They found Darwin's journal very interesting, stating that it was difficult to criticize due to its engaging content. Despite not being avid readers of travel books, they did not find any part of the journal tedious. They read much of it aloud as a test and concluded that it had more variety and interesting portions than other travel books. They believed it should be published separately from Captain FitzRoy's account.

3. **Catherine Wedgwood**: Like Fanny, she thought the journal should be published on its own rather than mixed with Captain FitzRoy’s writings.

Overall, while Henry Holland was cautious about publishing Darwin's journal independently due to potential overlap with existing accounts, the Wedgwoods and Catherine were enthusiastic about its standalone publication, finding it highly engaging and distinct from other travel narratives.

query: What plan did FitzRoy propose for dividing the work and profits from the volumes based on materials collected during their voyages, and how did Darwin respond to this proposal?

reference_answer:
FitzRoy proposed a collaborative plan where they would each write separate volumes based on the materials collected during their voyages. Specifically, one volume was suggested for King, another for Darwin, and a third for FitzRoy himself. The profits from these publications were to be divided equally into three portions among them.

Darwin agreed with this proposal and began working on his assigned volume. He planned to write a "kind of journal of a naturalist," focusing not strictly on chronological order but rather on the geographical positioning of their observations. Darwin intended for his volume to include extensive details about animal habits, geology sketches, descriptions of the country's appearance, and personal anecdotes. Additionally, he planned to later produce a detailed account of the geology and some zoological papers. This plan indicated that Darwin had significant work ahead for the next year or two, during which time he would not take any holidays.

query: Describe the structure and content Darwin intended for his volume in the planned series of publications. How did he plan to organize the information within it?

They agreed to review his journal. The physician and travel writer Henry Holland looked at some pages and "thought that it would not be worth while to publish it alone, as it would be partly going over the same ground with the Captain", leaving Darwin "more perplexed" but "becoming rather inclined to the plan of mixing up long passages with Capt Fitzroy." He would "go on with the geology and let the journal take care of itself", but Emma Wedgwood did not think Holland "any judge as to what is amusing or interesting", and like Catherine thought it should be published by itself, not "mixed up with Capt. FitzRoy\'s". Fanny and Hensleigh found the "Journal so interesting, that it is quite difficult to stop to criticize". Though "not in general a good reader of travels", he "found no part of yours tedious." They had "read a great deal of it aloud too" as a more severe test, and concluded it had "more variety and a greater number of interesting portions" than other travel books, "the less it is mixed up with the Captains the better." \nAfter advice from Broderip, FitzRoy wrote on 30 December that "One volume might be for King—another for you—and a third for me. The profits if any, to be divided into three equal portions—What think you of such a plan?" Darwin agreed, and began work on his volume. In March he told Fox "I am now hard at work and give up every thing else for it. Our plan is as follows.— Capt. FitzRoy writes two volumes, out of the materials collected during both the last voyage under Capt. King to T. del Fuego and during our circumnavigation.— I am to have the third volume, in which I intend giving a kind of journal of a naturalist, not following however always the order of time, but rather the order of position.— The habits of animals will occupy a large portion, sketches of the geology, the appearance of the country, and personal details will make the hodge-podge complete.— Afterwards I shall write an account of the geology in detail, and draw up some Zoological papers.— So that I have plenty of work, for the next year or two, and till that is finished I will have no holidays."']
reference_answer:
Charles Darwin intended for his volume in the planned series of publications to be structured as a "kind of journal of a naturalist." Unlike a traditional chronological account, he aimed to organize the content based on the order of position rather than strictly following the sequence of events. This approach allowed him to focus more on thematic elements and specific observations.

The content Darwin planned for his volume included several key components:

1. **Habits of Animals**: A significant portion of the volume was dedicated to exploring the behaviors and characteristics of various animals encountered during the voyage.

2. **Geology**: He intended to provide sketches and insights into the geological aspects observed, offering a glimpse into the earth's structure and composition in different regions visited.

3. **Appearance of the Country**: Descriptions of the landscapes and physical features of the places explored were also planned to be included, giving readers a vivid sense of the environments encountered.

4. **Personal Details**: Darwin aimed to incorporate personal anecdotes and reflections, adding depth and context to his scientific observations.

Overall, Darwin's volume was designed as a comprehensive "hodge-podge" that combined natural history with personal narrative, providing a richly detailed account of his experiences and findings during the voyage. This structure allowed him to delve deeply into specific topics while maintaining an engaging and varied narrative style.

query: How did Charles Darwin feel about becoming an author, and what specific event led him to express this sentiment?
reference_contexts:
['== Publication of FitzRoy's narrative and Darwin's book ==
Darwin reorganised his diary, trimmed parts, and incorporated scientific material from his field notes. He passed his writing to the publisher Henry Colburn, and in August 1837 had the first proofs back from the printer. Henslow helped check them; on 4 November, Darwin wrote to him that "If I live till I am eighty years old I shall not cease to marvel at finding myself an author". Part of it was printed, "the smooth paper and clear type has a charming appearance, and I sat the other evening gazing in silent admiration at the first page of my own volume, when I received it from the printers!"
FitzRoy had to edit King's account of the first voyage, adding extracts from the journal of the previous captain of Beagle and his own journal when he took over, as well as write his own account of the second voyage. In mid-November 1837, he took offence that Darwin's preface to volume III (and a similar preface to the first part of The Zoology) lacked, in his view, enough acknowledgement of the help given by FitzRoy and other officers; the problem was overcome. By the end of February 1838, King's Narrative (volumes I) and Darwin's Journal (volume III) had been printed, but FitzRoy was still hard at work on volume II.
The Narrative was completed and published as a four-volume set in May 1839, as the Narrative of the Surveying Voyages of His Majesty's Ships Adventure and Beagle, describing their Examination of the Southern Shores of South America, and the Beagle's Circumnavigation of the Globe, in three volumes. Volume one covers the first voyage under Commander Phillip Parker King, volume two is FitzRoy's account of the second voyage. Darwin's Journal and Remarks, 1832–1835 forms the third volume, and the fourth volume is a lengthy appendix. The publication was reviewed as a whole by Basil Hall in the July 1839 issue of the Edinburgh Review. 
Volume two includes FitzRoy's Remarks with reference to the Deluge in which he recanted his earlier interest in the geological writings of Charles Lyell and his remarks to Darwin during the expedition that sedimentary features they saw "could never have been effected by a forty days' flood", asserting his renewed commitment to a literal reading of the Bible. He had married on the ship's return, and his wife was very religious.
Darwin's contribution proved remarkably popular and the publisher, Henry Colburn of London, announced on 15 August a separate volume of Darwin's text, published with a new title page as Journal of Researches into the Geology and Natural History of the various countries visited by H.M.S. Beagle. The Publishers‘ Circular of 2 September carried an advertisement for this volume, as well as a separate advertisement for the other volumes, as listed at William Broderip's article in the Quarterly Review. This was apparently done without seeking Darwin's permission or paying him a fee.']
reference_answer: Charles Darwin felt surprised and somewhat amazed at finding himself as an author. He expressed this sentiment in a letter to his mentor John Stevens Henslow on November 4, 1837. In the letter, he wrote that "If I live till I am eighty years old I shall not cease to marvel at finding myself an author." This feeling was prompted by seeing the first proofs of his work from the printer and later gazing in admiration at the printed page of his volume. The specific event leading him to express this sentiment was receiving the first proofs back from the printer, which marked a significant step in the publication process of his narrative.

reference_answer: Captain FitzRoy reacted negatively to Darwin's preface in volume III of their publication because he felt it lacked sufficient acknowledgment of the help provided by FitzRoy and other officers. This caused him offense. The issue was eventually overcome, although the specific details of how it was resolved are not provided in the context information. It is likely that some form of negotiation or amendment to the preface occurred to address FitzRoy's concerns.

query: Describe the circumstances under which Darwin's contribution to the Narrative became a separate volume, including any actions taken by the publisher without his consent.
reference_contexts:
['== Publication of FitzRoy's narrative and Darwin's book ==
Darwin reorganised his diary, trimmed parts, and incorporated scientific material from his field notes. He passed his writing to the publisher Henry Colburn, and in August 1837 had the first proofs back from the printer. Part of it was printed, "the smooth paper and clear type has a charming appearance, and I sat the other evening gazing in silent admiration at the first page of my own volume, when I received it from the printers!"

By the end of February 1838, King's Narrative (volumes I) and Darwin's Journal (volume III) had been printed, but FitzRoy was still hard at work on volume II.
The Narrative was completed and published as a four-volume set in May 1839, as the Narrative of the Surveying Voyages of His Majesty's Ships Adventure and Beagle, describing their Examination of the Southern Shores of South America, and the Beagle's Circumnavigation of the Globe, in three volumes. Volume one covers the first voyage under Commander Phillip Parker King, volume two is FitzRoy's account of the second voyage. Darwin's Journal and Remarks, 1832–1835 forms the third volume, and the fourth volume is a lengthy appendix. The publication was reviewed as a whole by Basil Hall in the July 1839 issue of the Edinburgh Review. 
Volume two includes FitzRoy's Remarks with reference to the Deluge in which he recanted his earlier interest in the geological writings of Charles Lyell and his remarks to Darwin during the expedition that sedimentary features they saw "could never have been effected by a forty days' flood", asserting his renewed commitment to a literal reading of the Bible. He had married on the ship's return, and his wife was very religious.
Darwin's contribution proved remarkably popular and the publisher, Henry Colburn of London, announced on 15 August a separate volume of Darwin's text, published with a new title page as Journal of Researches into the Geology and Natural History of the various countries visited by H.M.S. Beagle. The Publishers‘ Circular of 2 September carried an advertisement for this volume, as well as a separate advertisement for the other volumes, as listed at William Broderip's article in the Quarterly Review. This was apparently done without seeking Darwin's permission or paying him a fee.']
reference_answer:
Darwin's contribution to the "Narrative of the Surveying Voyages" initially formed part of Volume III. However, due to its popularity, the publisher Henry Colburn decided to release it as a separate volume. This decision was made without seeking Darwin's permission or compensating him with a fee. On 15 August, Colburn announced this new publication under the title "Journal of Researches into the Geology and Natural History of the various countries visited by H.M.S. Beagle." The Publishers’ Circular on 2 September further advertised this separate volume alongside advertisements for the other volumes in the series.

This action highlights a lack of formal consent or financial arrangement with Darwin, as he was not consulted about the decision to publish his work separately nor did he receive any payment for it. Despite these circumstances, the separate publication contributed significantly to the dissemination and popularity of Darwin's observations and ideas.

query: What significant changes were made to the title and content of Darwin's work in its second edition published in 1845, and how did these reflect his evolving ideas on evolution?
reference_contexts:
['=== Second edition: changing ideas on evolution ===

The second edition of 1845 incorporated extensive revisions made in the light of interpretation of the field collections and developing ideas on evolution. This edition was commissioned by the publisher John Murray, who actually paid Darwin a fee of £150 for the copyright. The full title was modified to Journal of Researches into the Natural History and Geology of the countries visited during the voyage of H.M.S. Beagle round the world.
In the first edition, Darwin remarks in regard to the similarity of Galápagos wildlife to that on the South American continent, "The circumstance would be explained, according to the views of some authors, by saying that the creative power had acted according to the same law over a wide area". (This was written in a reference to Charles Lyell's ideas of "centres of creation".) Darwin notes the gradations in size of the beaks of species of finches, suspects that species "are confined to different islands", "But there is not space in this work, to enter into this curious subject."
Later editions hint at his new ideas on evolution:

Considering the small size of these islands, we feel the more astonished at the number of their aboriginal beings, and at their confined range... within a period geologically recent the unbroken ocean was here spread out. Hence, both in space and time, we seem to be brought somewhat near to that great fact – that mystery of mysteries – the first appearance of new beings on this earth.
Speaking of the finches with their gradations in size of beaks, he writes "one might really fancy that from an original paucity of birds in this archipelago, one species had been taken and modified for different ends."
In 1890, John Murray published an illustrated edition of the book, at the suggestion of the artist Robert Taylor Pritchett, who was already known for accompanying voyages of the RYS Wanderer and Sunbeam, and producing pictures used in books on these cruises. In his foreword to this edition of Journal and Researches, Murray said that most "of the views given in this work are from sketches made on the spot by Mr. Pritchett, with Mr. Darwin's book by his side", and the illustrations had been "chosen and verified with the utmost care and pains".


== Contents – places Darwin visited ==
For readability, the chapters of the book are arranged geographically rather than in an exact chronological sequence of places Darwin visited or revisited. The main headings (and in some cases subheadings) of each chapter give a good idea of where he went, but not the exact sequence. See second voyage of HMS Beagle for a detailed synopsis of Darwin's travels. The contents list in the book also notes topics discussed in each chapter, not shown here for simplicity. Names and spellings are those used by Darwin. The list below is based on the Journal and Remarks of 1839.

Preface
Chapter I: St. Jago–Cape de Verde Islands (St. Paul's Rocks, Fernando Noronha, 20 Feb.., Bahia, or San Salvador, Brazil, 29 Feb..)
Chapter II: Rio de Janeiro
Chapter III: Maldonado
Chapter IV: Río Negro to Bahia Blanca
Chapter V: Bahía Blanca
Chapter VI: Bahia Blanca to Buenos Aires
Chapter VII: Buenos Aires to St. Fe
Chapter VIII: Banda Oriental
Chapter IX: Patagonia
Chapter X: Santa Cruz–Patagonia
Chapter XI: Tierra del Fuego
Chapter XII: The Falkland Islands
Chapter XIII: Strait of Magellan
Chapter XIV: Central Chile
Chapter XV: Chiloe and Chonos Islands
Chapter XVI: Chiloe and Concepcion
Chapter XVII: Passage of Cordillera
Chapter XVIII: Northern Chile and Peru
Chapter XIX: Galapagos Archipelago
Chapter XX: Tahiti and New Zealand
Chapter XXI: Australia (Van Diemen's Land)
Chapter XXII: Coral Formations (Keeling or Cocos Islands)
Chapter XXIII: Mauritius to England
In the second edition, the Journal of Researches of 1845, chapters VIII and IX were merged into a new chapter VIII on "Banda Oriental and Patagonia", and chapter IX now included "Santa Cruz, Patagonia and The Falkland Islands". After chapter X on Tierra del Fuego, chapter XI had the revised heading "Strait of Magellan–Climate of the Southern Coasts". The following chapters were renumbered accordingly. Chapter XIV was given the revised heading "Chiloe and Concepcion: Great Earthquake", and chapter XX had the heading "Keeling Island:–Coral Formations", with the concluding chapter XXI keeping the heading "Mauritius to England".


== Notes ==']
reference_answer:
In the second edition of Charles Darwin's "Journal of Researches," published in 1845, several significant changes were made both to the title and content that reflected his evolving ideas on evolution.

### Title Changes:
1. **Full Title Modification**: The full title was changed from its original form to "Journal of Researches into the Natural History and Geology of the countries visited during the voyage of H.M.S. Beagle round the world." This change emphasized a broader scope, focusing more explicitly on natural history and geology.

### Content Changes:
1. **Revised Chapters**: The structure of the book was altered by merging chapters VIII and IX into a new chapter titled "Banda Oriental and Patagonia," while chapter IX now included content about "Santa Cruz, Patagonia and The Falkland Islands." Additionally, after chapter X on Tierra del Fuego, chapter XI was re-titled to "Strait of Magellan–Climate of the Southern Coasts." These changes reflect a more organized presentation of Darwin's observations.

2. **Reflecting Evolving Ideas**: In this edition, Darwin began hinting at his developing ideas on evolution. For instance:
   - He expressed astonishment at the number and confined range of aboriginal species in small islands, suggesting proximity to understanding "the first appearance of new beings on this earth."
   - Regarding finches with varied beak sizes, he speculated that from an original paucity of birds, one species might have diversified for different purposes. This idea foreshadows his later theory of natural selection.

3. **Illustrations**: An illustrated edition was published in 1890 based on sketches made by Robert Taylor Pritchett during Darwin's travels. These illustrations were chosen and verified with care, adding a visual dimension to the observations recorded in the book.

Overall, these changes in title and content reflect Darwin's shift from merely documenting his observations to contemplating broader evolutionary concepts, setting the stage for his later work on natural selection.

Chapter XVII: Passage of Cordillera

Chapter XIX: Galapagos Archipelago
Chapter XX: Tahiti and New Zealand

In the second edition, the Journal of Researches of 1845, chapters VIII and IX were merged into a new chapter VIII on "Banda Oriental and Patagonia", and chapter IX now included "Santa Cruz, Patagonia and The Falkland Islands". After chapter X on Tierra del Fuego, chapter XI had the revised heading "Strait of Magellan–Climate of the Southern Coasts". The following chapters were renumbered accordingly. Chapter XIV was given the revised heading "Chiloe and Concepcion: Great Earthquake", and chapter XX had the heading "Keeling Island:–Coral Formations", with the concluding chapter XXI keeping the heading "Mauritius to England".

reference_answer:
John Murray played a significant role in the publication of Charles Darwin's "Journal of Researches." He was responsible for commissioning the second edition, which was published in 1845. This edition incorporated extensive revisions reflecting Darwin's developing ideas on evolution and interpretations from field collections. John Murray also paid Darwin a fee of £150 for the copyright to this revised work. The full title of the book was modified under his direction to "Journal of Researches into the Natural History and Geology of the countries visited during the voyage of H.M.S. Beagle round the world."

In 1890, John Murray again contributed to Darwin's work by publishing an illustrated edition of the book. This decision came at the suggestion of Robert Taylor Pritchett, a noted artist who had accompanied voyages on ships like the RYS Wanderer and Sunbeam. Pritchett was known for producing illustrations used in books about these cruises. In his foreword to this illustrated edition, Murray highlighted that most views presented were based on sketches made by Pritchett at the locations described in Darwin's book. These illustrations had been "chosen and verified with the utmost care and pains," ensuring their accuracy and relevance to the text.

Thus, John Murray was instrumental both in revising and expanding Darwin's work for its second edition and later enhancing it visually through collaboration with Robert Taylor Pritchett for the 1890 illustrated edition.

reference_answer:
In the second edition of Charles Darwin's "Journal of Researches" (1845), several chapters underwent reorganization and merging. Specifically, for chapters VIII through XI:

1. **Chapters VIII and IX** were merged into a new chapter titled "Banda Oriental and Patagonia." This revised chapter covered geographical areas that included Banda Oriental (present-day Uruguay) and Patagonia.

2. The original Chapter IX was expanded to include content from the former Chapter X, resulting in it covering "Santa Cruz, Patagonia, and The Falkland Islands."

3. **Chapter XI** was renumbered and given a new heading: "Strait of Magellan–Climate of the Southern Coasts." This chapter focused on the Strait of Magellan and discussed the climate along the southern coasts.

These changes reflect Darwin's efforts to consolidate related geographical areas into single chapters, providing a more cohesive narrative about his observations in those regions.

query: Based on Charles Darwin's works and biographical sources, which publication provides insights into his experiences as a traveler during his voyage on the HMS Beagle?

reference_answer:
Based on the provided context information, several publications offer insights into Charles Darwin's experiences as a traveler during his voyage on the HMS Beagle. Notably:

1. **"Darwin, C. R. [Beagle diary (1831-1836)]. EH88202366, Darwin Online"** - This is a transcription of Darwin’s own diary from the Beagle voyage, providing firsthand accounts and observations.

2. **Keynes, Richard (2001), "Charles Darwin's Beagle Diary," Cambridge University Press** - This publication likely offers an edited version or analysis of Darwin's original diary entries during his journey on the HMS Beagle.

3. **Browne, E. Janet (1995), "Charles Darwin: vol. 1 Voyaging"** - As part of a comprehensive biography series, this volume specifically focuses on Darwin’s voyages, including his time aboard the HMS Beagle.

4. **Thomson, Keith S. (2003), "HMS Beagle: The story of Darwin's ship," London: Phoenix** - This book provides context about the ship itself and its significance in Darwin's journey.

These sources collectively provide detailed insights into Darwin’s experiences as a traveler during his voyage on the HMS Beagle.

1. **"Charles Darwin: vol. 1 Voyaging"** (1995) - This volume focuses on the early years of Darwin, particularly his journey aboard the HMS Beagle, which was crucial in shaping his scientific ideas.

These volumes provide comprehensive insights into different phases and influences in Darwin’s life and scientific career.

reference_answer: The "Darwin Online" resource is significant because it provides a transcription of Charles Darwin's Beagle Diary (1831-1836), which is an essential primary source for understanding his observations and experiences during the voyage of HMS Beagle. This diary offers insights into Darwin's early thoughts, scientific inquiries, and the development of ideas that later contributed to his theory of evolution by natural selection. The transcription makes these valuable historical documents accessible to researchers, students, and anyone interested in Darwin's work and life. By providing detailed accounts from this period, "Darwin Online" serves as a crucial tool for studying Darwin's contributions to science and the broader context of 19th-century exploration and natural history.

query: Who was the commander of the first expedition (1826–30) documented in "Voyages of the Adventure and Beagle, Volume I," and where was this volume published?
reference_contexts:
["=== Bibliography of original publications ===
Voyages of the Adventure and Beagle, Volume I – King, P. Parker (1839), Proceedings of the first expedition, 1826–30, under the command of Captain P. Parker King, R.N., F.R.S, Great Marlborough Street, London: Henry Colburn Retrieved on 30 April 2007
Voyages of the Adventure and Beagle, Volume II – FitzRoy, Robert (1839), Proceedings of the second expedition, 1831–36, under the command of Captain Robert Fitz-Roy, R.N., Great Marlborough Street, London: Henry Colburn Retrieved on 15 December 2006
Voyages of the Adventure and Beagle, Volume III – Darwin, Charles (1839), Journal and remarks. 1832–1836., London: Henry Colburn{{citation}}:  CS1 maint: publisher location (link) (The Voyage of the Beagle) Retrieved on 30 April 2007
Voyages of the Adventure and Beagle, Appendix – FitzRoy, Robert (1839b), Appendix, Great Marlborough Street, London: Henry Colburn Retrieved on 15 December 2006
Darwin, Charles (1845), Journal of researches into the natural history and geology of the countries visited during the voyage of H.M.S. Beagle round the world, under the Command of Capt. Fitz Roy, R.N. (Second ed.), London: John Murray{{citation}}:  CS1 maint: publisher location (link) (The Voyage of the Beagle) Retrieved on 30 April 2007

Charles Darwin's Great Adventure: Voyage of the Beagle Without the Science"]
reference_answer: The commander of the first expedition (1826–30) documented in "Voyages of the Adventure and Beagle, Volume I" was Captain P. Parker King, R.N., F.R.S. This volume was published at Great Marlborough Street, London by Henry Colburn.
